species.name: Doryaspis
species.description: An Early Devonian pteraspid from Spitzbergen. It had a broad triangular head shield with a forward-projecting rostrum, a prominent dorsal spine, and a spiky upper surface for predator defense. Its ventral mouth suggests it fed on bottom organisms, and its hydrofoil shape allowed for rapid, controlled movement.

species.name: Boreaspis
species.description: An Early Devonian pteraspid from Spitzbergen, characterized by a narrow head shield with a snout that curved down to sweep muddy bottoms, suggesting a feeding strategy on the muddy floor.

species.name: Arandaspis
species.description: An Early Ordovician agnathan from Australia. This primitive jawless fish had a head shield covered by small bony plates, a sensory line system, and two eye openings with a single nostril on its upper surface.

species.name: Jamoytius
species.description: A Silurian agnathan from Scotland, it was a small, eel-like creature without a backbone. It possessed a narrow tubular snout, a dorsal fin extending along its back, and a caudal fin for propulsion.

species.name: Drepanaspis
species.description: An Early Devonian pteraspid from Germany. It had a broad, flat, horseshoe-shaped head shield covering its eyes, a body covered by a mosaic of small plates, and a caudal fin for thrust.

species.name: Dartmuthia
species.description: An Early Devonian ostracoderm from Europe. It was a small, torpedo-shaped fish with a head shield covered in small bony plates, a flattened head shield, a prominent dorsal spine, two large lateral spines, and openings for eyes and a single nostril.

species.name: Pteraspis
species.description: An Early Devonian pteraspid from Europe, featuring a typical heterostracan head shield covered with small dermal plates and two spines, one on its back and one on the lower side.

species.name: Hemicyclaspis
species.description: An Early Devonian cephalaspid from Europe with a broad, horseshoe-shaped head shield that covered its eyes, gills, and brain, along with a small, torpedo-shaped body.

species.name: Pharyngolepis
species.description: An Early Silurian thelodont from Norway. This small, jawless fish had a well-developed dorsal fin and a caudal fin that would have aided in swimming.

species.name: Thelodus
species.description: An Early Silurian thelodont found worldwide. It was a small, jawless fish with a body covered by small bony scales, an extended caudal fin, and a small dorsal fin.

species.name: Tremataspis
species.description: A Late Silurian osteostracan from Europe. This small, jawless fish had a large, flat, shovel-shaped head shield that covered most of its body.

species.name: Ischyodus
species.description: A Middle Jurassic to Early Paleocene chimera or rat fish from Europe. It was a small, long-bodied fish with a long, pointed snout and a large dorsal fin.

species.name: Deltoptychius
species.description: An Early Carboniferous chimera from Europe. It possessed a deep, shovel-like head with a short pointed snout and large pectoral fins.

species.name: Hybodus
species.description: A Middle Triassic to Late Cretaceous shark found worldwide. It had two dorsal fins, a large caudal fin, and small spines.

species.name: Xenacanthus
species.description: A Permian freshwater shark found worldwide. It was an eel-like shark with a long dorsal fin, a long caudal fin, and a spine on its head.

species.name: Cobelodus
species.description: An Early Carboniferous shark from North America. It was a small, deep-bodied shark with a short snout and a large dorsal fin.

species.name: Tristychius
species.description: An Early Carboniferous shark from Scotland. It was a small, slender shark with a long caudal fin and two dorsal fins.

species.name: Scapanorhynchus
species.description: A Late Cretaceous shark found worldwide, distinguished by a long, pointed snout, two dorsal fins, and a large caudal fin.

species.name: Stethacanthus
species.description: An Early Carboniferous shark from North America, known for its flat, shovel-like dorsal fin and a broad, flat pectoral fin.

species.name: Cladoselache
species.description: An Early Late Devonian shark from North America. This small, streamlined shark had a long, symmetrical caudal fin, two dorsal fins, and seven gill slits.

species.name: Spathobathis
species.description: A Late Jurassic ray from Europe. It had a broad, flat body with a long tail, large pectoral fins, a pointed snout, and small spines.

species.name: Dunkleosteus
species.description: A very large, armored fish with a massive head shield and powerful jaws. It was a Late Devonian placoderm found worldwide.
